repnme.cdata!:
Lebanon - Vocational and Technical
            Education Project

abstracts.cdata!:
Project ratings are as follows: Project
            outcome is unsatisfactory; sustainability is unlikely;
            institutional development impact is modest; Bank performance
            is unsatisfactory; and Borrower performance is
            unsatisfactory. The project provides the following key
            lessons: 1) Vocational and technical education (VTE)
            projects are impeded by a strong political expansionary
            dynamic in the country, retarded by an equally strong
            institutional inertia; an absence of, and/or inability, to
            recruit professionals having the range of technical,
            managerial, and leadership skills necessary to facilitate
            change in a multi-stakeholder environment; and the absence
            of effective mechanisms to fully engage employers as
            partners in the human capital  development process. These
            facts suggest that the Bank should continue to focus on this
            sector; not make investments without an explicit and
            coherent policy environment; adopt a reform orientation as
            opposed to a development orientation, with government
            required to give specific commitments to implementing reform
            before it can borrow; investments should be progressive,
            focusing early on building the knowledge base to guide
            reforms and develop institutional capacity to implement
            them; and part of the investment should be channeled to
            developing employer based institutions so they become
            effective partners in the reform process. 2) The VTE sector
            is commonly used to serve a blend of social and economic
            objectives. In Lebanon, this is seen in objectives expressed
            by government at the time of project preparation, to expand
            the number of places in VTE programs. This proposed
            expansion was clearly unfounded and not based on an
            identified labor market or economic demand, but primarily
            based on a need to absorb a growing youth population, and
            provide them some form of employment linked skills.   3)
            Interventions in the sector should be founded on identified
            and prioritized strategic gaps in the system, long term, and
            progressive as opposed to attempting to "fix" the
            system through the lens of a single project. 4) No VTE
            project should be initiated without being able to
            irrevocably demonstrate through the project preparation
            process, an employer community commitment to partnership. 5)
            The project design process should include a sector wide
            assessment of financial sustainability in order to guide the
            investment. 6) The project design process should place
            greater emphasis on analyzing the internal characteristics
            of the implementation environment. This would include
            specific assessment of the range and depth of technical
            competencies, the characteristics of the regulatory
            framework, internal cultural behavior, information and
            decision-making processes, financial resources, and prior
            experience in project implementation. The project design
            should subsequently include components that support
            institutional change and development from within if
            sustainability is to be achieved. 7) More rigorous
            management processes should be adopted by the Bank to
            guarantee that peer review comments are substantially
            addressed in project design. 8) The availability of the TTL
            in the field to provide guidance at the ministerial level,
            resolve differences at the institutional level, or provide
            technical advice at the operational level enabled valuable
            outputs from a troubled project to be captured and sustained.

repnme.cdata!:
Lebanon - Vocational and Technical
            Education Project

abstracts.cdata!:
The development objective of the
            Vocational and Technical Education Project is to improve the
            performance of the Vocational and Technical Education (VTE)
            system by making it more demand driven and responsive to
            market needs.  Its components are: 1) Institutional
            strengthening and capacity building through: a)
            strengthening MVTE's management, planning, financial
            control capabilities, marketing and research; b) developing
            VTE policies including defining public/private sector roles
            in training, improving cost recovery, and increasing
            women's participation in the labor market; c) campaigns
            to improve the image of VTE and public attitude towards it;
            and d) establishing and maintaining a Project Implementation
            Unit (PIU).  2) Improvement of relevance, responsiveness and
            quality of training through: a) addressing current and
            expected training demand, including development of training
            programs that would attract women into more productive jobs;
            b) developing quality standards; c) developing modern
            curricula; and d) improving pre and in-service training of
            teachers.  3) Delivery mechanisms improvement through: a)
            improving the efficiency of existing VTE schools by
            rehabilitating, expanding and re-equipping them; and b)
            developing new fields (Model Schools) in sectors with growth
            potential in partnership with the private sector.
